name: wrecking

present participle of
wreck
C2 to destroy or badly damage something: The explosion shattered nearby windows and wrecked two cars. Our greenhouse was wrecked in last night's storm.
informal to spoil something completely: He has been warned that his behaviour might wreck his chances of promotion.
More examplesFewer examplesThe man is demented - he's going to wreck the whole operation.The storm wrecked our garden shed.The children have wrecked my camera.
